Brown & Williamson Voice/February 6
wysiwyg://206/http://www.bw.com/voice/feb6.html
4
B&W RESPONDS TO ALLEGATIONS OF MARKETING TO YOUTH
February 6, 1997
Brown & Williamson yesterday submitted the following letter to the Washington Post and The Courier-Journal in response to an article alleging that B&W marketed to underage smokers:
Contrary to what the headline in today's (Feb. 5) Washington Post would have readers believe, "Documents Indicate Strategy of Targeting Teen Smokers," Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation has not and does not market cigarettes to underage smokers.
The trumpeting of a 23-year old document commonly referred to as the "Bates Memo" to support the allegation of targeting youth is a prime example. This document, a 1975 report from an outside marketing consultant to an outside ad agency, was used by the media almost 20 years ago to claim that B&W was marketing to children. It became the subject of a major court case that resulted in one of the largest libel awards ever. When a CBS news reporter charged in 1981 that this document showed B&W was marketing to children, B&W sued for libel -- and won a multi-million dollar court judgment. The jury found that the allegation that B& W marketed to children was not true and awarded millions of dollars in damages to B&W. As the jury trial brought to light, B& W had not only rejected the report, but also fired the advertising agency which requested the report. B&W does not now, nor did it then, market cigarettes to children.
Another example is a 25-year old memo from outside consultants. This document did, as our opponents charge, recommend that the company consider a "sweet-flavor" cigarette like a cola-flavored cigarette. But the facts show that a "sweet-flavor" cola cigarette was never implemented. The proof is clear to anyone who simply looks at the marketplace now and back over the last 25 years. Has anyone ever seen a cola-flavored cigarette in the marketplace? The answer is no.
All of which brings up a point for consideration. In the course of conducting any business over 30 or 40 years, plenty of ill-conceived or inappropriate ideas are bound to be suggested. It is easy to make allegations based on old documents containing such ideas.
Brown & Williamson has not engaged in advertising or marketing efforts designed to target youth. For more than two decades, it has been B&W's explicit policy to direct its advertising, marketing, sales, sampling and promotional programs only to persons 21 years of age and over.

February 6, 1997

by the media almost 20 years ago to claim that B&W was

children.

consultants. This document did, as our opponents charge,
